Today, I opposed H.R. 21, the so-called Midnight Rules Relief Act. This bill is a solution to a problem that does not exist and undermines critical protections for students, workers, taxpayers and consumers.  As my colleague, Congressman Hank Johnson, stated in November, 2016 about the Midnight Rules Relief Act it "...would amend the Congressional Review Act to enable Congress to bundle numerous rules finalized during the final year of a president’s term into a single vote on a joint resolution of disapproval.  Alarmingly, once these rules have been invalidated through this process, the agency may not adopt a subsequent similar rule absent express authorization by Congress.  Notwithstanding the bill’s colorful title, the bill does not simply apply to rules submitted during the lame-duck period following an election.  To set the record straight, this bill applies to every rule submitted to Congress within the final 60 legislative days of a session. "  http://www.huffingtonpost.com/rep-hank-johnson/the-so-called-midnight-ru_b_13074236.html

Today's confirmation hearing for Secretary of Education nominee Betsy DeVos causes me extreme concern for the future of public education during the Trump administration. The Secretary of Education is tasked with strengthening public education and the department cannot be lead effectively by someone with no experience in public education and whose career has been built on privatizing it.   http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/betsy-devos-trump-s-pick-education-secretary-won-t-rule-n708171

Betsy DeVos is not qualified to lead the Department of Education. DeVos has no public or higher education experience. She has spent decades fighting to expand for-profit charter schools and tax payer-funded vouchers for private and religious schools.  Her nomination is an attack on our public schools, our students, and our teachers.  During last night’s hearing, DeVos showed a shocking lack of understanding of our nation’s education system. Further, she refused to rule out reducing funding for public education, refused to fight to keep guns out of schools, and refused to stand up for campus sexual assault victims.   Chairman Alexander should never have allowed this hearing to take place prior to the Office of Government Ethics completely vetting DeVos.   Yesterday, I joined 67 of my colleagues in sending a letter to the Senate HELP committee urging them to vote ‘no’ on DeVos because our students deserve a Secretary of Education who will stand up for public education, fight for educational equity, and uphold the civil rights of all students. After last night’s hearing, it is even clearer that Betsy DeVos is not that person. If you value public education and the safety of our children, I urge you to call your Senator and demand a ‘no’ vote.

Our first #BlackHistoryMonth artist spotlight is on Romare Bearden of Charlotte, N.C. Bearden was born in 1911 and passed away in 1987 at age 76. The breadth of his work covered his many interests including race politics, performing arts, history, literature, and music. His diverse work spans from richly textured collages that were featured on the covers of Fortune and Time magazine to the luxurious costume designs used for famous dance theaters. Over his lifetime he received many awards including but not limited to an honorary doctorate from the Pratt Institute, the Mayor’s Award of Honor for Art and Culture in New York City, and the National Medal of Arts which was presented by President Ronald Reagan.

Today's #BlackHistoryMonth artist spotlight is on LeGrant Taylor of Angier, NC. When Taylor was in kindergarten, doctors discovered that he was legally blind in his left eye due to a birth defect. Taylor has chosen to view this visual impairment as a “gift” that gives him a unique perspective in his art. Taylor studied Printing Technology at Chowan College and is now a full time Printing Press Operator in Garner, NC.  Having received no formal art training outside of a junior high school art class, Taylor is a self-taught artist who uses oil on canvas to paint from the souls’ eye. He has been featured on UNC-TV’s “Men at Art”, on Arts Now (the digital home for the Triangle arts community) as an “Artist to Watch”.  This piece of artwork is entitled "Know Looking Back".

Yesterday, we celebrated 100 years since the first woman was elected to Congress and tomorrow marks 54 years since the Equal Pay Act was signed into law, yet women across our nation still face a pay disparity for the work they do. Ahead of Equal Pay Day tomorrow, I'm proud to be an original cosponsor of the Paycheck Fairness Act again this year to ensure that women earn equal pay for equal work.

Equal Pay Day symbolizes when, more than three months into the year, women’s wages finally catch up to what men were paid in the previous year. Last week during the Women's Symposium and Networking Fair Mecklenburg County Women reflected on what Equal Pay Day means to them:

It takes the average woman an additional 94 days—three additional months—to earn what her male peers earned in 2016. That is unacceptable.  From the North Carolina House to the U.S. House, I have been fighting to close gender and wage gaps. Fifty-four years have passed since we signed the Equal Pay Act into law, but today in North Carolina, women still only make 82 cents for every dollar a man makes – and nationally, that statistic is even worse.  When women are shortchanged our children, families and economy are shortchanged. Today, I am calling on my colleagues to join me in working to close gender and wage gaps by passing the Paycheck Fairness Act.

I'm proud to introduce the Closing the Meal Gap Act of 2017 to fight hunger in the 12th District and across our country.    “In Mecklenburg County alone, over 158,000 people participate in the SNAP program and, too often, SNAP benefits are just not enough for those who struggle to put food on the table,” said Congresswoman Adams.  “The Closing the Meal Gap Act will strengthen the SNAP program for families, adults looking for work, seniors and the disabled.”  Specifically The Closing the Meal Gap Act of 2017 would:  • Permanently authorize a standard medical deduction in every state for seniors and disabled individuals applying for SNAP benefits. • Incorporate the Low-Cost Food Plan into the SNAP formula to take into account how much working people, including SNAP recipients, spend on food. • Eliminate the cap on the Excess Shelter Deduction in the SNAP formula to take into account the cost of living for SNAP recipients in areas with high rent and utilities. • Raise the minimum SNAP benefit from $16 to $25 per month. • Allow Able-Bodied Adults to be exempt from SNAP work requirements if their state cannot provide them with a slot in a SNAP Employment and Training Program (also known as SNAP E&T).  https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/1276/text

Today I️ introduced the Protecting Education and Pathways to Opportunity Tax Package with nine of my colleagues. This package includes eight amendments to the Republican tax bill that ensure all Americans have access to quality education and opportunities for upward mobility.   I️ introduced this package following a letter I️ sent to Ways and Means Chairman Kevin Brady and House Speaker Paul Ryan outlining the tax priorities of the 12th District. When this bill moved out of Ways and Means Committee it didn’t include any of our priorities so I️ offered these amendments to ensure our concerns weren’t falling on deaf ears.   The amendments include:  1. Reinstating the tax exempt status of private use bonds, used to build infrastructure and affordable housing;  2. Reinstating the student loan interest tax deduction, making higher education more affordable; 3. Repealing the tax on tuition waivers and student stipends, protecting student’s access to higher education; 4. Instating a provision that makes HBCU Tax Bonds exempt from federal, state, and local taxes, incentivizing investment in HBCU bonds and increasing access to capital at HBCUs; 5. Incentivizing the hiring of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) graduates from minority serving institutions (MSI), creating pathways to opportunity for underserved communities;  6. Instating the Veterans Small Business Tax Credit, assisting veterans in becoming small business owners;  7. Repealing the tax on discharged student loans, releasing students from crushing student loan debt;  8. Repealing the tax on university and college endowments, increasing the capital available for investment in campus infrastructure and student scholarships.   Middle class families and small businesses need real tax relief but the GOP bill falls flat. These amendments are the first step in providing access to opportunity for all Americans.

As we prepare for the first winter weather of the season please keep these helpful tips in mind:   •Store an emergency kit in your vehicle. Include scraper, jumper cables, tow chain, sand/salt, blankets, flashlight, first aid kit and road map.  •Always keep at least a three-day supply of non-perishable food in your home.  •Keep fresh batteries on hand for weather radios and flashlights. •Dress warmly for the cold. Wear multiple layers of thin clothing instead of a single layer of thick clothing.  •Properly vent kerosene heaters and keep electric generators outside and away from open windows or doors to prevent carbon monoxide poisoning. Do not burn charcoal indoors.  •Use a NOAA Weather Radio or monitor local news media for changing weather conditions.  •Keep alternative heating sources and fire extinguishers on hand. Today, I offered an amendment to the PROSPER Act which repeals the Majority’s 25% grad/transfer rate requirement for certain minority serving institution (MSI) grant funds. It provides additional allowable uses of existing MSI grant programs, and establishes multiple programs to support MSIs and the students they serve. Lastly, the amendment includes an $850 million MSI Innovation fund, to provide sustained funding on these campuses to drive innovative approaches to improving college completion, STEM degree attainment, and connection to the private sector.  “Minority serving institutions are routinely forced to do more with less. The PROSPER Act presents an opportunity to remedy that by fully and equitably funding these institutions but unfortunately, this bill does nothing to create opportunities for students at MSIs or HBCUs to prosper. Instead, it denies resources to the neediest schools based on a flawed metric,” said Congresswoman Adams. “MSIs serve a unique student population comprised of minority, non-traditional, and first generation college students. Instead of stripping them of much-needed resources, we should be investing in the students they serve to give them the best chance possible to complete their education.”    http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/congress/article189427944.html
